Introduction

Chiari malformations (CMs) are structural abnormalities at the craniocervical junction where portions of the cerebellum and/or brainstem herniate through the foramen magnum into the spinal canal.  CMs are classified into types I-III based on the degree of herniation and associated anomalies.  These malformations can result in various neurologic symptoms, depending on the severity, type, and associated complications.

Anatomy and pathophysiology



The cerebellum normally sits within the posterior cranial fossa and above the foramen magnum, which contains the medulla, nerves, and vasculature (

figure 1
); CMs are a group of congenital disorders caused by the underdevelopment of the posterior fossa.  The small size of the fossa causes parts of the cerebellum and potentially the medulla to herniate through the foramen magnum, compressing these structures.



There are 3 types of CMs:



  • CM type I:  The most common type, characterized by low-lying cerebellar tonsils that extend below the foramen magnum into the vertebral canal.
  • CM type II:  Also referred to as Arnold-Chiari malformation, characterized by the downward displacement of the cerebellum (vermis and tonsils) and medulla through the foramen magnum.
  • CM type III:  A severe form, often characterized by herniation of the cerebellum into a cervical or occipital encephalocele and displacement of the brainstem through the foramen magnum.


Compromised cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamics can lead to other features, including spinal cord defects (eg, syringomyelia, meningomyelocele) and noncommunicating hydrocephalus (due to CSF outflow obstruction in the posterior fossa).  Each CM type is discussed in more detail.

CM type I

Clinical presentation



CM-I is the most common and mildest subtype.  Patients are often asymptomatic throughout childhood and may either be diagnosed incidentally on imaging or develop symptoms in adolescence or early adulthood.  Symptoms usually develop slowly, and patients may have:



  • Paroxysmal occipital headache:  Due to meningeal irritation (most frequent symptom).
  • Cerebellar dysfunction (eg, dizziness, ataxia):  Due to compression of the cerebellar tonsils.


Symptoms classically occur with physical activity or Valsalva maneuvers (eg, cough, straining) due to pressure of the cerebellar tonsils on the foramen magnum.  If the malformation progresses and becomes more severe, signs of increased intracranial pressure (eg, vomiting, early morning headache), and/or cranial neuropathies from brainstem compression (eg, dysarthria) may occur.  Dysfunction of the respiratory centers in the brainstem or those that control muscles in the mouth and throat may also cause sleep apnea.



Syringomyelia, a disorder in which a cyst (syrinx) forms in the spinal cord, occurs in about 30% of patients with CM-I (

image 1
).  The syrinx is most commonly located in the cervical region, and syrinx expansion may result in progressive neurologic dysfunction, including the loss of pain and temperature sensation in a cape-like distribution and/or upper extremity weakness.  Scoliosis, which can occur due to weakness of the paraspinal muscles, may be the only sign of syringomyelia in children and may prompt an early diagnosis of CM-I.

Diagnosis



Neuroimaging, usually with an MRI of the brain and the whole spinal cord, is required to make the diagnosis of CM-I and assess for associated syringomyelia.  MRI characteristically shows downward displacement of elongated cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum and into the upper cervical canal (

image 2
).  Specialized imaging to visualize CSF flow through the foramen magnum is useful for treatment planning.  Patients with CM-I may need polysomnography if symptoms suggestive of sleep apnea are present.

Management and prognosis



CM-I without symptoms (or with mild symptoms) is often managed conservatively with observation and analgesics for headaches if needed.  For patients who are symptomatic or have significant blockage of CSF flow, neurosurgical evaluation for potential posterior fossa decompression is recommended.  The prognosis for CM-I is usually good, particularly in patients who are asymptomatic or only mildly symptomatic; individuals who need surgical decompression often show improvement after the procedure.

CM type II

Clinical presentation



CM-II refers to the downward displacement of both the cerebellum and the medulla through the foramen magnum.  CM-II is almost always associated with myelomeningocele (eg, spina bifida).  In myelomeningocele, CSF is lost through the open neural tube defect, causing the collapse of cranial structures; this collapse results in the development of a small posterior fossa and, subsequently, CM-II.  The malformation often causes an obstructive hydrocephalus by limiting CSF flow through the fourth ventricle and/or cerebral aqueduct.



Symptoms of CM-II are typically evident during the neonatal period (

figure 2
) and can include:



  • Enlarging head circumference, bulging fontanelles, and poor feeding after birth due to obstructive hydrocephalus (

  • Dysphagia, stridor, and/or apnea due to compression of the medulla.


The myelomeningocele associated with CM-II is visible at birth and can cause lower limb paralysis with bowel/bladder incontinence.

Diagnosis



Prior to birth, fetal ultrasonography can show evidence of spinal myelomeningocele, which usually prompts further imaging with fetal MRI; this allows for the detection of CM-II before birth.  If fetal imaging is unavailable, CM-II can be detected with MRI of the brain after birth, which shows displacement of the cerebellum and medulla through the foramen magnum (

image 3
).

Management and prognosis



Almost all patients with CM-II require neurosurgical evaluation to determine the treatment of associated neural tube defects (eg, myelomeningocele) and related complications (eg, shunting for hydrocephalus).  CM-II has a variable prognosis that depends on the severity of herniation.  Infants who show signs of hydrocephalus with significant brainstem compression have a worse prognosis with a high mortality rate, particularly in the first few years of life.  Infants with mild CM-II symptoms have a better prognosis; however, they may still have neurologic dysfunction and will likely have long-term complications associated with myelomeningocele.

CM type III



CM-III is the rarest and most severe subtype.  Patients have an encephalocele, which is a protrusion of most of the cerebellum (and occasionally the occipital cortex) through an abnormal opening in the skull.  This is often diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (followed by fetal MRI).  Symptoms at birth are severe and can include feeding difficulties, apnea/respiratory issues, seizures, and abnormal tone.  Mortality in infants with CM-III is high, and infants who survive often have severe developmental delays.

Differential diagnosis



The differential diagnosis of CMs includes:



  • Dandy-Walker malformation:  Characterized by hypoplasia/absence of the cerebellar vermis and cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle with enlargement of the posterior fossa.
  • Holoprosencephaly:  Characterized by incomplete development and separation of the embryonic forebrain (prosencephalon) and often associated with midfacial defects.
  • Cerebellar stroke:  Vascular event characterized by the occlusion of blood flow to the cerebellum.  This often presents with acute-onset occipital headache, dizziness, and ataxia, usually in patients with cardiovascular risk factors.  Neuroimaging typically shows a lesion in a vascular territory.
  • Multiple sclerosis:  An autoimmune demyelinating disorder of the CNS that typically presents in young adult women with neurologic deficits disseminated in space and time.  Neuroimaging typically shows periventricular white matter lesions.

Summary



Chiari malformations encompass a group of structural hindbrain abnormalities resulting in varying degrees of cerebellar/brainstem herniation.



  • Chiari malformation type I is often diagnosed incidentally in asymptomatic patients in childhood or with occipital headaches and/or cerebellar dysfunction (eg, ataxia) in adolescence or young adulthood; patients may have associated syringomyelia.
  • Chiari malformation type II is usually diagnosed in neonates and involves herniation of the cerebellum and medulla through the foramen magnum, leading to hydrocephalus and more severe neurologic symptoms; it is almost always associated with myelomeningocele.
  • Chiari malformation type III is the most severe type and involves herniation of the cerebellum (and occasionally the occipital cortex) into an encephalocele.


Diagnosis relies on MRI of the brain and often the spinal cord, with treatment tailored to symptom severity and complications.
